root.pub-comments: “All Polynesian languages are considered to be descended from Proto-Polynesian” (Langdon and Tryon 1983:15).

child.pub-comments: “The four member languages of the proposed Futunic subgroup share at least six lexical innovations which indicate a period of development in common” (Langdon and Tryon 1983:34).

“The evidence for the inclusion of Rapanui in a putative 'Proto-Futunic' subgroup, as in Figure 6, is not strongly supported because the loss of the Proto-Polynesian glottal stop in all Nuclear Polynesian languages other than East Futunan, East Uvean, Rennellese/Bellonese, and Rapanui is the only evidence for establishing the subgroup” (Langdon and Tryon 1983:28). “Rapanui is directly descended from a Futunic subgroup of Proto-Nuclear Polynesian and it acquired Central Eastern Polynesian features through borrowing from the Central Eastern group of languages” (Langdon and Tryon 1983:48).
child.tree-val: Polynesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Langdon and Tryon 1983
child.publications: Langdon, Robert & Darrell T Tryon. 1983. The Language of Easter Island: Its Development and Eastern Polynesian Relationships, 73. Laie, Hawaii: The Institute for Polynesian Studies. ISBN 0-939154-32-3
child.geography: spoken on Easter Island, most easterly island in Polynesia, lying well over 2,000 miles south-eastward of Tahiti and 2,230 miles from the coast of Chili; located at 27° 10' S latitude, 109° 20' W longitude

child.pub-comments: “There is some doubt about the linguistic history of East Uvean, the language of Wallis Island, because it has features common to both the Tongic and Nuclear Polynesian groups. Some of East Uvean's Tongic features are due to the influence of Tongan invaders in recent centuries, and Pawley and Biggs have concluded that it should be grouped with the Nuclear Polynesian languages” (Langdon and Tryon 1983:15).
